body: Holidaymakers could find themselves bagging a cheaper seat on the plane this summer after Ryanair announced it would cut air fares by an average 7%, raising the prospect of a further price war between airlines. The Irish no-frills carrier said it would drop fares to keep its planes full, with demand hit by economic uncertainty and terror attacks, as lower fuel costs cut the cost of flying. Ryanair, Europe’s biggest airline by passenger numbers, expects prices to drop by around 5-7% this summer, and as much as 12% in winter. Chief executive Michael O’Leary said that fares would be lower primarily because of extra supply of seats, in Ryanair’s fleet and others, while lower oil prices were filtering through to cut costs. The airline has taken delivery of 41 new 737s from Boeing in the last year with a further 52 coming this year, as it looks to grow passenger numbers to more than 100m. “It’s good, because customers are going to get lower air fares and it also puts downwards pressure on our competitors.” According to the International Air Transport Association, fares to and from European destinations had already fallen 11.4% in the first three months of 2016 compared with the same period last year. Britain’s largest carrier, easyJet, said earlier this month it had cut fares to lure wary passengers. The Ryanair boss’s outlook suggests competition will be fierce and fares will remain low, as analysts predict other carriers likely to follow suit. Robin Byde at Cantor Fitzgerald said: “Ryanair is a major player in many of the markets and airports it flies to. If it cuts prices, other airlines will have to respond to that.” O’Leary vowed: “If there is a fare war in Europe, then Ryanair will be the winner.” A euro billionaire, O’Leary imposed a pay freeze on middle and senior management and vowed costs would continue to fall, as the airline reported net profits up 43% to €1.24bn (£960m) for 2015-16. Hedging to buy oil at lower oil prices means that the airline’s fuel bill will be €200m lower next year, while new aircraft with more seats and better fuel consumption will also cut costs significantly, O’Leary added. The terrorist attacks in Brussels and Paris, as well as air traffic control strikes in France, also pushed fares down with fewer people looking to travel in the aftermath. O’Leary said the EgyptAir disaster, in which a passenger jet with 66 people aboard crashed into the sea between Paris and Cairo last week, had also affected bookings: “It has already had an affect on business, bookings were weak on Thursday, Friday, Saturday. We respond by lowering fares and bookings return to normal, but at lower prices.” O’Leary said the impact would be felt in fares for three to five months, but he did not expect any new security procedures even if terrorism was behind the latest air disaster. He said Ryanair, which only flies to Morocco in North Africa, had conducted its own audits of airport security, alongside European and Irish audits, and revealed that the airline had been concerned about the safety of airports in Egypt where it had been considering opening routes. “We had certain concerns about some of the airports in North Africa that we don’t fly to but have been in discussions about. There were concerns expressed at the Egyptian airports, but the Egyptians have significantly improved the state of security at their airports. Meanwhile, O’Leary repeated his support for Britain staying in the EU and defended Ryanair’s offer of cheap fares for expats to fly home to vote for UK’s continued membership. Police are investigating Ryanair’s “Brexit special” ad after the Vote Leave campaign claimed it broke the Bribery Act by offering discounts in exchange for votes. “The leave side have so run out of ideas that the best they can come up with is reporting me to the Metropolitan police,” he said. “Now they believe that Ryanair offering lower fares to UK customers is somehow endangering democracy in the UK,” O’Leary said.  He said the airline would be extending its referendum seat sale, adding: “We want to thank them sincerely for the two days of additional PR we got out of it.”
webTitle: Ryanair fares cut could prompt price war
